texts.definition: Agents controlled by the game system that follow and help players as they move through the game environment.
markups: <style="Definition">Agents controlled by the game system that follow and help players as they move through the game environment.</style>

Like in other endeavors, it may be easily to succeed in games if one has help. While these may be other people, games can also provide characters and other entities, commonly called <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>, that follow the players progress and try to help. They may be gained and lost during gameplay or may be incorporeal presences only giving advice, but provide players support in overcoming problems or offer new ways of trying to do so.

Many roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> allow players to get trained animals, hirelings, mercenaries, etc. with their game masters permission. The control of these are typically shared in some way, with game masters having the final authority but doing as the players' order as long as it is does not clash with the <style="CurrentLink">Companions'</style> natures.

The side-scrolling arcade game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Shadow%20Dancer">Shadow Dancer</link></style> provides players with a canine <style="CurrentLink">Companion</style> that can help attack enemies that are otherwise difficult to get to. The action-adventures <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fable%20II">Fable II</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> also provide players with a pet that accompany them in their adventures. They can help in combats as well as provide some additional support, such as identifying treasures and being able to exit dungeons to sell loot respectively.

The games of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> allow players to convince various inhabitants of the post-apocalyptic world to join them in their quests (how many and which depending on what game in the series). These companions provide different types of competences, will only agree to collaborate with the players if they behave in certain ways, and do for some of the games have their own story lines and quests.

The advisors present in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civiliation series</link></style> can be seen as a form of <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>. Like the player, they have no direct manifestation within the game world but they do follow players' progress throughout the ages and provide tips and tricks.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> consists of selecting characteristics for <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> so that they can function as <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> to players. To do this, they need to have either <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> with a player. They may be able to work towards these through having the same <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> as the players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> have, or have different ones to fill different <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> - especially so if these are <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. For <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> with anything else than a trivial internal state, i.e. those making use of the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> pattern, one also has design choices regarding which <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> to provide them with.

<style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are often <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> with all design choices this infers. However, since they often are in <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> with players it is more likely that they support <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> than is the case for other <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. Since these are likely to be interacted with more than other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>, it may be more important than otherwise to make them into believable <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. This includes creating <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>, considering questions of <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> (in both directions) and <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> (especially when one can have more than one <style="CurrentLink">Companion</style>, introducing memberships in different <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, and deciding to which degree, if any, they should have an <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style> is appropriate as well although it can conflict with being a willing follower - this may be solved by instantiating it through <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> for examples of this). Besides other ways their fates can be unfolded, <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> may turn out to be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. Regardless of the specific ways that <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> can behave towards the player's <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar">Avatar</link></style>, how he or she behaves to them can easily be made into <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> (examples of this can be found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>) and affect future behavior of the <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> provided with computer-based <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> are able to constantly react to the players' actions but they can also be controlled by <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>. The latter provides more flexibility to support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style> and handle unexpected situations so that <style="Link"><link="awareness-surroundings">Awareness of Surroundings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> can be maintained and one can avoid breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are not players per se, since their definitions is that they should accompany a player. Even if they may be more powerful than players in some areas, so that different <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> can be filled, players do need to have some <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> in relation to the <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>. These abilities may at a minimum be to have the power of actually completing goals and controlling the group's <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> (so the game doesn't play itself and players can become <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>) but typically include many other abilities so players have an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> compared to the <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>. For these reasons, <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> differ from <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> used to fill <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. Although <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> could be used to help players from states of <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, this is not solution seen often in game designs.

Gaining <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> can be as simple as striking up a <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogue</link></style> with them or being part of a <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structure</link></style> that is enforced through an <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Event</link></style> (see the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style> for the latter). It may also be a <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> for completing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style>) or an <style="Link"><link="investments">Investment</link></style> if paid for with <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>. If players have to choice which <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> to have due to the number of <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> being limited or due to hostile opinions between them, they are a form of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>. This is also the case if they can die and the pool of possible <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are a <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> - allowing <style="Link"><link="friendly-fire">Friendly Fire</link></style> on <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> can make this more of a problem and thereby provide more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>. Some roleplaying games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> allow players to create <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> as part of creating their <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, this make the <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> an example of <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>. While gaining <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> can provide players with access to their <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> takes this one step further by awarding specific <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> through perks that are added when <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are gained.

Like other types of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> can have <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>. However, the <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> can be <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> for the players as well by proxy.

When <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are optional players may not be aware that they are available. This can be told through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> such as having them be part of <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style>.

As <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> noticing player behavior, <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are well-suited to provide instructions and comments about how to perform actions in the game (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style>). Although this may break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> it may can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> without ruining <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Engrossment">Engrossment</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>.

An <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screen</link></style> is typically required if players are to be able to give <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> instructions on how they should behave or trade <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> with them (e.g. the 'companion wheel' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style>).

As <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> which have a reason to be in close proximity to players' <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, they provide a natural focus for <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. These can be part of the main storyline of a game or as <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style> (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> for examples of this).

Having <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> leave <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> due to players' <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Having Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> is a way to both modulate how <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> work and create events which are likely to be main events of the overall game story.

<style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> are <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> to players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Characters</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and may make up supporting members in players' <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>. The use of them when they are controlled by <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> can be seen as a way of creating <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> although there is only one player in the <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. As <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> often are partly defined as <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, they are also often examples of <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> and can often be used to fill the <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> than that players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do not fill. When this is done by having specific <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> the player doesn't have, this is an instance of providing <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> by proxy. By providing help, they can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> (especially if they are connected to a system for <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style>) and can support <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>. They also provide a target for players' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> besides the <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> themselves.

<style="CurrentLink">Companions</style> that can be lost are a source of <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, as are those that may be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> or otherwise commit acts of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>.

Since players are more powerful than their <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>, even if this is only through their control of these <style="CurrentLink">Companions</style>, the use of the pattern is one way of providing an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> compared to other inhabitants in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. They are often needed for, and modulated by, a game's <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agenda</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>
